statement.text: A Mersenne prime is a prime number of the form Mₚ = 2^p - 1, where p itself must be prime. Not all Mersenne numbers (2^p - 1 with prime p) are prime; those that are prime are called Mersenne primes.
statement.formal: Mₚ is a Mersenne prime ⟺ (Mₚ = 2^p - 1) ∧ (p is prime) ∧ (Mₚ is prime)

explanation.intuition: Mersenne primes are among the largest known primes because the form 2^p - 1 is relatively easy to test for primality using specialized algorithms. They're named after Marin Mersenne, a 17th-century French monk who studied these numbers. Think of them as 'one less than a power of 2'—in binary, they're numbers with all 1's (e.g., 7 = 111₂, 31 = 11111₂).
explanation.key_insight: Mersenne primes are fundamentally connected to perfect numbers through the Euclid-Euler theorem: every even perfect number corresponds to a unique Mersenne prime via the formula 2^(p-1) × (2^p - 1). This ancient connection, spanning 2000+ years, remains one of number theory's most elegant relationships.
explanation.technical_details: If 2^n - 1 is prime, then n must be prime (though the converse is false). The Lucas-Lehmer test provides an efficient deterministic primality test specifically for Mersenne numbers, running in O(p²) time for testing Mₚ. As of 2024, only 51 Mersenne primes are known. The largest known prime number is always a Mersenne prime due to GIMPS (Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search) distributed computing project.
common_misconceptions: All Mersenne numbers are prime—FALSE: M₁₁ = 2047 = 23 × 89 is composite
If p is prime, 2^p - 1 is always prime—FALSE: counterexample is 2^11 - 1 = 2047 (composite)
Mersenne primes are rare—TRUE: only 51 known, increasingly rare as numbers grow
Finding Mersenne primes is easy—FALSE: despite efficient tests, finding new ones requires massive computation

definitions_glossary.mersenne_number: A number of the form Mₙ = 2^n - 1 (may or may not be prime)
definitions_glossary.lucas_lehmer_test: Efficient deterministic test for Mersenne primality
definitions_glossary.GIMPS: Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search—distributed computing project
definitions_glossary.perfect_number: A number equal to sum of its proper divisors; even perfects linked to Mersenne primes
definitions_glossary.double_mersenne_prime: A Mersenne prime Mₚ where p itself is a Mersenne prime

properties: If 2^n - 1 is prime, then n must be prime
In binary, Mersenne primes are repunits (all 1's)
Every even perfect number corresponds to a Mersenne prime
Mersenne primes are always of the form 6k + 1 or 6k - 1
No known pattern for which p gives Mersenne primes

lucas_lehmer_test.algorithm: Define S₀ = 4; Sᵢ₊₁ = (Sᵢ² - 2) mod Mₚ. Then Mₚ is prime ⟺ Sₚ₋₂ ≡ 0 (mod Mₚ)
lucas_lehmer_test.efficiency: Extremely efficient for Mersenne numbers; far faster than general primality tests

pedagogical.historical_context: Marin Mersenne, a French monk and mathematician, studied these numbers in the 17th century. His original 1644 list contained errors, but gave rise to the name. The Lucas-Lehmer test (developed 1878-1930) made testing Mersenne numbers efficient. GIMPS, started in 1996, has found most recent Mersenne primes through distributed computing.
